data_source: District of West Vancouver, BC dive club surveys
notes: Designated Marine Protected Area. Close to Vancouver, excellent training site, diverse invertebrate communities.

name: SS-S-038
habitat: Deep water inlet, strong currents, rocky walls
sswd_observations: Documented SSWD impact in deeper populations
data_source: WDFW dive surveys, recreational dive reports
notes: Major entrance to Puget Sound. Deep water habitat with historical sea star populations.

name: SS-S-020
location: Between Orcas Island and Fidalgo Island, WA
habitat: Open water strait, rocky reefs, kelp forests
pycnopodia_documentation: Open water Pycnopodia habitat connecting San Juan Islands
sswd_observations: Strait populations affected by SSWD outbreak
notes: Major waterway between islands with diverse depth ranges and habitats.

name: SS-S-082
habitat: Urban bay, mixed substrate, recovering ecosystem
pycnopodia_documentation: Urban environment Pycnopodia habitat, restoration area
notes: Urban marine environment with ongoing habitat restoration efforts.

name: SS-S-035
habitat: Ferry terminal jetty, artificial structure, protected water
pycnopodia_documentation: Popular dive site with documented sea star populations
data_source: Whidbey Island diving community, WDFW surveys
notes: Ferry terminal dive site popular with local divers. Jetty structure provides habitat for marine life.

name: SS-S-083
habitat: Protected beach, mixed substrate, training site
notes: Popular training site in south Puget Sound with predictable but mild currents.

name: SS-S-072
habitat: Point habitat, consistent south current, rocky reef
notes: Consistent current pattern, popular advanced dive site with diverse marine life.

name: SS-S-074
habitat: Marina environment, artificial structures, protected water
notes: Marina diving with artificial habitat structures supporting marine communities.

name: SS-S-075
habitat: State park beach, rocky/sandy substrate, protected cove
pycnopodia_documentation: State park waters with documented invertebrate populations
notes: Only saltwater state park in King County. Popular diving and training location.

name: SS-S-046
habitat: Ferry terminal area, artificial structures, mixed substrate
pycnopodia_documentation: North Sound Pycnopodia habitat near ferry operations
notes: Ferry terminal diving location with accessible entry and diverse marine habitat.

name: SS-S-081
habitat: Ferry terminal area, mixed substrate, moderate current
pycnopodia_documentation: Vashon Island SSWD monitoring mentioned in early reports
data_source: Early SSWD outbreak reports, MARINe updates
notes: One of early SSWD observation locations. Ferry terminal access to diverse habitat.

name: SS-S-022
habitat: Deep inlet, anoxic deep waters, diverse shallow habitat
sswd_observations: BC SSWD monitoring in inlet system
notes: Research inlet with extreme depth gradient. Shallow areas support diverse invertebrate communities.

name: SS-N-028
habitat: Gulf Islands habitat, rocky shores, kelp forests
notes: Gulf Islands marine diversity. Important habitat for multiple sea star species.

name: SS-S-005
habitat: Largest Gulf Island, diverse marine habitats
sswd_observations: SSWD outbreak monitoring in Gulf Islands
notes: Largest Gulf Island with extensive shoreline and diverse marine habitats.

name: SS-S-008
habitat: Twin island system, protected waters, rocky habitat
pycnopodia_documentation: Gulf Islands marine diversity including sea stars
notes: North and South Pender Islands with protected inter-island waters.

name: SS-N-031
habitat: Shallow bay, mixed fresh/salt influence, mud/sand flats
pycnopodia_documentation: Boundary waters habitat, lower salinity influence
notes: International boundary waters with Fraser River influence. Unique brackish habitat conditions.

name: SS-N-022
habitat: Glacial fjord, deep water, steep walls
notes: Deep glacial fjord extending into North Shore mountains. Steep underwater topography.

name: SS-N-024
habitat: Urban harbor, shipping channel, varied depth
pycnopodia_documentation: Urban marine environment with sea star populations
notes: Major urban harbor and shipping channel. Habitat restoration and monitoring programs active.

name: SS-N-027
habitat: Harbor and open coast, ferry terminal, diverse depth
pycnopodia_documentation: Vancouver Island east coast Pycnopodia habitat
data_source: BC marine monitoring, ferry terminal surveys
notes: Major Vancouver Island center with harbor and open coast access. Ferry connection to mainland.

name: SS-N-017
habitat: Outer Gulf Islands, exposed coast, kelp forests
notes: REEF monitoring expansion site 2019. Outer Gulf Islands location with more exposed conditions.

name: JDF-011
habitat: Ecological reserve, exposed waters, strong current
pycnopodia_documentation: Marine ecological reserve with documented sea star diversity
notes: Race Rocks Ecological Reserve. High current, high diversity marine environment.

name: JDF-008
habitat: Harbor breakwater, artificial structure, protected water
data_source: Victoria area dive clubs, marine monitoring
notes: Inner harbor artificial breakwater structure. Popular urban diving location.

name: WA-O-001
source: emeralddiving.com dive site coordinates + habitat description
habitat: rocky canyon / kelp forest / boulder fields
sswd_status: suitable habitat with diverse large invertebrate populations
notes: Advanced dive site south of Tatoosh Island. Two massive rock walls forming underwater canyon with boulder fields. Kelp forest habitat with diverse invertebrate populations including large sea stars. Access from Neah Bay (8 miles).

name: WA-O-003
habitat: rocky reef / kelp forest / exposed coast
sswd_status: historically documented, current status unknown
notes: 0.5 miles offshore from Cape Flattery, westernmost point of contiguous US. Part of Makah Indian Reservation. Surrounded by kelp forests and rocky habitat suitable for Pycnopodia.

name: WA-O-002
source: NOAA Olympic Coast monitoring + geographic references
habitat: rocky reef / kelp forest / exposed headland
sswd_status: part of Olympic Coast National Marine Sanctuary monitoring
notes: Northwestern tip of Olympic Peninsula. Multiple dive sites off Cape Flattery accessible from Neah Bay. Part of OCNMS monitoring area with documented kelp forest communities.

name: WA-O-004
source: NWFSC subtidal monitoring access point + marine sanctuary data
habitat: rocky reef / kelp forest / protected bay
sswd_status: NWFSC annual subtidal surveys document sea star populations
notes: Primary access point for NWFSC annual kelp forest monitoring. Scientists access Olympic Coast study sites from here. Makah tribal area with traditional sea star habitat.

name: WA-O-006
source: Trailforks GPS coordinates + Olympic NP documentation
habitat: rocky intertidal / sea stacks / kelp beds
sswd_status: pristine Olympic NP habitat, historical Pycnopodia populations documented
notes: Northwestern Olympic National Park. Point of Arches sea stacks provide diverse intertidal and subtidal habitat. 15-mile wild beachfront corridor to Cape Alava.

name: WA-O-008
source: Olympic National Park + MARINe monitoring network
habitat: rocky intertidal / kelp forest / exposed headland
sswd_status: MARINe long-term monitoring site since 2008
notes: Westernmost point of contiguous US. Olympic NP wilderness area. MARINe rocky intertidal monitoring with documented sea star populations. Ozette Triangle access.

name: WA-O-005
source: Bull kelp habitat documentation + geographic references
habitat: rocky reef / bull kelp beds / exposed point
sswd_status: documented kelp forest habitat suitable for Pycnopodia
notes: Between Neah Bay and Shi Shi Beach. Documented bull kelp (Nereocystis) and giant kelp (Macrocystis) beds. Traditional Makah fishing and diving area.

name: WA-O-012
source: NWFSC monitoring access point + Quileute tribal area
habitat: rocky reef / kelp forest / river mouth
sswd_status: NWFSC annual subtidal surveys access point
notes: Mouth of Quillayute River. Second access point for NWFSC Olympic Coast kelp forest monitoring. Quileute Indian Reservation. WDFW Marine Area 3 northern boundary.

name: WA-O-013
source: Olympic National Park + tide pooling guides
habitat: rocky intertidal / sea stacks / kelp patches
sswd_status: Olympic NP pristine intertidal habitat
notes: 1.4-mile trail from La Push. Sea stacks and tide pools. Popular for intertidal exploration and documented sea star populations before SSWD.

name: WA-O-014
source: Olympic National Park tide pool documentation
habitat: rocky intertidal / kelp patches / sandy beach
sswd_status: documented tide pool habitat with historical sea star populations
notes: 1.3-mile trail from La Push. Mix of rocky and sandy habitat. Extensive tide pool areas documented for sea star diversity prior to SSWD outbreak.

name: WA-O-015
habitat: rocky headland / kelp forest / sea stacks
sswd_status: remote Olympic NP wilderness, minimal human impact
notes: Remote headland between Third Beach and Hoh River. Accessible only by backpacking. Pristine kelp forest habitat in Olympic Coast wilderness.

name: WA-O-017
habitat: rocky beach / sea stacks / kelp patches
sswd_status: popular ONP beach with documented intertidal diversity
notes: Near Ruby Beach, famous for sea stacks and sunset views. Mix of rocky intertidal and sandy beach habitat. Highway 101 access makes it well-documented for marine life.

name: WA-O-018
source: Olympic National Park official site + tide pool guides
habitat: rocky intertidal / sea stacks / drift logs
sswd_status: well-documented ONP tide pool habitat
notes: Most accessible Olympic Coast beach from Highway 101. Famous sea stacks and extensive tide pooling. Well-documented marine invertebrate populations including historical Pycnopodia.

name: WA-O-022
source: Olympic National Park tide pool documentation + visitor guides
habitat: rocky intertidal / tide pools / sandy beach
sswd_status: excellent tide pool habitat with documented sea star diversity
notes: Most popular tide pooling beach in Olympic NP. Documented for excellent intertidal diversity including sea stars. Easy access from Kalaloch Lodge area.

name: WA-O-021
source: Olympic National Park + Whale Trail documentation
habitat: rocky intertidal / sandy beach / offshore kelp
sswd_status: documented marine habitat with historical sea star populations
notes: Kalaloch Lodge area. Whale Trail viewing site. Mix of sandy and rocky habitat with documented kelp beds offshore. Historical Pycnopodia habitat.

name: WA-O-023
source: Olympic National Park southern boundary documentation
habitat: rocky patches / sandy beach / scattered kelp
sswd_status: ONP southern coastal boundary
notes: Southern end of Olympic National Park coastal strip. Transition zone between ONP and Quinault tribal lands. Scattered rocky habitat suitable for sea stars.

name: WA-O-019
habitat: rocky reef / kelp forest / offshore island
sswd_status: offshore island habitat within OCNMS boundaries
notes: 30-acre island 3.5 miles offshore. Part of Quillayute Needles National Wildlife Refuge. NOAA weather buoy station. Deep kelp forest habitat surrounding island.

name: WA-O-025
source: Quinault Indian Nation traditional fishing areas
habitat: sandy beach / scattered rocky areas / kelp patches
sswd_status: tribal lands with traditional knowledge of sea star populations
notes: Quinault Indian Reservation coastal area. Traditional fishing and gathering grounds. Quinault Nation participates in MARINe monitoring on outer Olympic Coast.

name: WA-O-026
source: OCNMS southern boundary + clam digging area documentation
habitat: sandy beach / rocky patches / river mouth
sswd_status: southern boundary of Olympic Coast National Marine Sanctuary
notes: Southern limit of OCNMS. Copalis River mouth creates diverse habitat. Mixed sandy and rocky areas. Popular razor clam digging beach with documented intertidal life.

name: WA-O-027
habitat: sandy beach / rocky patches / offshore reefs
sswd_status: transition zone between OCNMS and Grays Harbor region
notes: Small coastal town. Transition between Olympic Coast and Grays Harbor regions. Mixed habitat with offshore rocky reefs suitable for kelp and sea stars.

name: WA-O-028
source: Washington State Parks + Grays Harbor documentation
habitat: sandy beach / jetty rocks / protected bay areas
sswd_status: primarily sandy habitat, limited rocky areas at jetties
notes: North jetty of Grays Harbor entrance. Primarily sandy habitat but jetty rocks provide some hard substrate. Views across to Westport. Limited sea star habitat.

name: WA-O-030
source: WDFW Marine Area documentation + fishing port
habitat: jetty rocks / sandy bottom / marina structures
sswd_status: artificial hard substrate provides limited sea star habitat
notes: Major fishing port and charter boat hub. South jetty of Grays Harbor provides rocky habitat. Marina structures create artificial reef habitat suitable for some sea stars.

name: WA-O-031
habitat: sandy beach / scattered rocks / surf zone
sswd_status: primarily sandy habitat, very limited rocky substrate
notes: South of Westport. Primarily sandy beach habitat. Limited rocky substrate. More important for razor clams than sea stars, but included for geographic completeness.

name: WA-O-033
sswd_status: estuarine habitat, not typical Pycnopodia environment
notes: Entrance to Willapa Bay. Primarily estuarine and sandy habitat. Limited hard substrate. Important shellfish area but not typical sea star habitat.

name: WA-O-035
source: Washington State Parks + Long Beach tourism
habitat: sandy beach / scattered driftwood / surf zone
sswd_status: extensive sandy beach, very limited rocky habitat
notes: 28-mile sandy beach peninsula. World's longest drivable beach. Primarily sandy habitat with limited hard substrate for sea star attachment. Included for geographic coverage.

name: WA-O-036
source: Washington State Parks GPS coordinates + lighthouse location
habitat: rocky headland / jetty rocks / exposed coast
sswd_status: rocky headland habitat suitable for sea stars
notes: Southern tip of Long Beach Peninsula. Rocky headland at Columbia River mouth. North Head Lighthouse location. Rocky habitat suitable for Pycnopodia populations. Lewis & Clark National Historical Park.
